header.title: History of the Simal project
header.abstract: This document describes the steps taken to set up and maintain the Simal project.

audience.title: Intended Audience
audience.p: Anyone interested in the history of the Simal project.

purpose.title: Purpose
purpose.p: This document should not be misconstrued as the definitive history of the Simal project. Rather it attempts to take account of each significant decision-point as it came along. Our memories are faulty at best, and we hope this is a way to provide some guidance for other projects that might wish to go down a similar path; guidance both for what to do, and for what not to do.

section.title: Initial discussion of possible project for OSS Watch
section.p: Although members of the OSS Watch team had bandied the idea of setting up an open source development project themselves for some time, discussion in earnest did not begin until the addition of Ross Gardler to the team in January 2007. Ross' experience as a member of The Apache Software Foundation, his concerted focus on the need to develop a community around any open development project, and his practical suggestion of a framework for building a DOAP catalogue solidified our wishful thinking into something more like the seed of a project.
However, even with the seed of a project in place, we faced a set of immediate decisions:

ul.li: should this project be set within Oxford University Computing Services (where the OSS Watch team is located)
should we use an established open source project hosting site, such as SourceForge or Google Code

would this project be intended to serve more than just the end of producing a particular software application
the project could be a means of developing reusable documentation for other open development projects
the project could be a means of establishing a new practice of open development at Oxford University Computing Services
the project could be a means for OSS Watch staff to learn by doing through participation in an open development project
what licence should we choose for our code and our documentation
how would we get other user/developers involved
what steps could we take now to make the project sustainable in the long run

section.p: There were other considerations as well but the above probably constitute the most significant points. With so many decision points the project could easily have turned into a talking point rather than an actual open development project. Fortunately that did not turn out to be the case.

section.title: First Codebase
section.p: On Friday, 2 March 2007, Ross Gardler sent an email to the other members of the OSS Watch team entitled: Simal is born (DOAP catalogue). In that email, Ross outlined the initial thrust of the project, where the codebase for the project was located, and how we could each begin contributing.
section.source:
I just committed Simal to our new projects svn space.
Simal is the current working title for the DOAP catalogue. If you want to suggest a real name please go ahead - however names should not reflect what the project does, things tend to go in unexpected directions in open source.
Current Status ==============
The catalogue is currently in an early prototype stage. To view the current catalogue functionality follow the links in the catalogue menu on the left of the above linked page. For more information about the current status and recent changes in the catalogue code see the recent changes document (you can subscribe to a changes RSS feed if you prefer - note this is a temporary location for the feed).
What Needs to be Done =====================
In order to move forward with the development of the catalogue we need to increase the number of projects represented with DOAP files, and we need to extend the information stored in current projects files. The files are stored at \src\documentation\content\rdf feel free to edit them (until the project finds a permanent home I'm happy for everyone to have commit access to the code base).
Since Ramon showed some interest, it would also be really cool if we could have a package for Simal and for Forrest to make the getting start part even easier. I have no idea how to do this but there are plenty of people in the building who can help. It would be great if Ramon could also donate the config for doing the Forrest part back to the Forrest community.
Getting Started ===============
Try this document for size [with a link to the Quick Start doc on the seed project site]
section.p: The initial codebase was deposited in an OSS Watch projects subversion repository. That was always meant to be a temporary holding point until we made some early decisions.
With a subversion repository accessible to the OSS Watch team, the project could be said to have officially started.

section.title: Initial discussion
section.p: Throughout those first few days the team engaged in wide-spread discussion about a number of issues. More than 50 emails were exchanged on the team email list.

ul.li: which licence should the project adopt?
the project name - what does Simal mean?; nothing, it's just a name

what do we do if we want to contribute a patch to the Apache Forrest project?
the initial project site and codebase for Simal drew heavily on the achievements of the Apache Forrest project. It was perfectly natural therefore that participants in Simal might also find opportunities to contribute to the Apache Forrest project. In order for that to take place, however, since the team members were all employees of the University of Oxford, an Apache Coporate Contributor License Agreement would need to be signed on our behalf by someone with the authority to do so, in this case the Director of Oxford University Computing Services.
have we set up the initial subversion repository correctly?

section.p: Lots to think about and lots to decide.

section.title: First Contributions
section.p: Within days of being started the Simal project recieved important contributions from other OSS Watch members. Many of these contributions were not technical in nature, but are good examples of the non-technical contributions new users of a project can make quickly and easily. These contributions included:

ul.li: Expansion of DOAP data available to the system
Contribution of an external DOAP file from a third party project, in this case WebPA at Loughborough University

section.p: These contributions show the value of the release early, release often approach commonly found in open source software development. Early releases enable early feedback and contributions from interested parties. As long as user expectations are managed correctly, for example known bugs are clearly identified in the release documentation, exposing your early work, "warts and all" is the start to building an early community.

section.title: Early decisions
section.p: Before one month had passed the team discussion had reached consensus on two important points:

ul.li:
licence: Apache License, version 2.0
After intensively exploring a number of options the consensus was that Simal should be released under the Apache License, version 2.0. This licence was chosen as we believe that it provides the most flexibility for likely downstream projects wishing to utilise the Simal outputs. In addition it also address a possible long term plan for the sustainability of the project

project home: Google Code
Hosting the project on Google Code serves a number of ends. Google Code has many of the advantages of SourceForge without the association with more than 100,000 moribund projects. It has Google behind it, which bodes well for the ongoing development of its facilities. No one in the team had used it before (other than to explore its feature set), so it would provide a learning opportunity for everyone. Plus we thought it would be fun.

section.title: Agreement of plans from copyright holders and funding bodies
section.p: OSS Watch, who are the first intended users of the Simal system, are a part of Research Technologies Service at Oxford University Computing Services (OUCS). Since OSS Watch time will be donated to this project it was necessary to get approval from OSS Watch's Director at OUCS before making this project public.

To this end Ross Gardler and Randy Metcalfe of OSS Watch created a project description brief that looked at the immediate benefits to OSS Watch, JISC (the Joint Information Systems Committee) - OSS Watch's funder, and OUCS. This was submitted to Mike Fraser, Director of OSS Watch who approved the allocation of 0.1 FTE to the project over 4 months. Not much, but enough to get things going.
Next stage is to take this project description to Ann Borda, OSS Watch's JISC Programme Manager.
